repnme.cdata!:
China - First and Second Ertan
            Hydroelectric Projects, Sichuan Power Transmission Project,
            and Zhejiang Power Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings for the First and Second
            Ertan Hydroelectric Projects, Sichuan Power Transmission
            Project, and Zhejiang Power Development Project for China
            are as follows: For each of the four projects, the project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is high; Bank performance
            is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is satisfactory.
            The experience gained under the three projects reviewed in
            this report, as well as from the pursuit o f concurrent
            power sector reforms at the national level in China, offers
            these general lessons: 1) Power shortages are a barrier to
            the pursuit of market reforms aimed at increasing
            competition. 2)  Effective regulatory arrangements should be
            in place at the same time (if not sooner) as power supply
            entities are unbundled, in order to reduce abuses of market
            power. 3)  Indicative power system planning at the national
            level is essential in order to avoid boom-bust investment
            cycles such as the one currently building up in the Chinese
            power sector.

6073748.trustfund:
TF026652-PHRD-CHINA: IMPLEMENTATION OF
            THE ERTAN II HYDROELECTRIC PROJECT - INCO,TF020761-AUSTRALIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST

            I/CFS CONL'T

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sichuan Power Transmission Project
            for China had a satisfactory outcome, with likely
            sustainability, substantial institutional development
            impact, and satisfactory performances by both the Bank and
            Borrower. The Project substantially achieved its physical
            and policy objectives albeit with some delays and
            shortcomings.  Lessons learned in the area of project design
            include: a) major sector reforms require a flexible approach
            with performance indicators emphasizing satisfactory
            progress in an agreed overall direction rather than acting
            as detailed benchmarks that may turn out to be unrealistic;
            b)  to minimize project implementation delays, especially
            for critical components, it is important to secure financial
            arrangements before Board presentation; and it would be
            prudent to obtain written commitments from local financiers;
            and c)  it is important to develop a detailed plan for
            compensation at the time of appraisal, with evaluation of
            unforeseen risks and provision for suitable cost escalation.
            In the area of project implementation, lessons learned
            included: a) while the Project demonstrated that it is
            possible to construct high-voltage transmission networks in
            mountainous areas at reasonable cost, procurement design
            should carefully evaluate the capacity and capability of
            local contractors as well as the interface of specifications
            with foreign suppliers; and b) in evaluating the progress in
            projects requiring substantive restructuring, the Bank
            should periodically review the key indicators to determine
            if they remain valid or need fine-tuning.

18224985.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific
18224985.theme: Pollution management and environmental health,Climate change,Regulation and competition policy,Infrastructure services for private sector development
18224985.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sichuan Power Transmission Project
            will: (a) alleviate an acute shortage of electricity by the
            construction of a 500-kV transmission network for connecting
            the ongoing Ertan hydroelectric project to the Sichuan power
            grid, as well as reinforcing the existing power transmission
            system; (b) assist in designing and implementing a
            time-bound program to implement power subsector reforms in
            Sichuan Province; (c) support the implementation of further
            power tariff rationalization; (d) promote transfer of
            contemporary technologies for extra-high voltage
            transmission networks; (e) strengthen institutional
            capabilities for environmental management and operation
            capabilities through well-focused staff training programs.
            The project will include: (a) construction of an new 500-kV
            transmission network; (b) carrying out of environmental
            management and resettlement programs; (c) extension of
            technical assistance for implementation of the State
            Planning Commission's reform plan, organization
            improvements, and development of accounting and financial
            management systems; and (d) provision of engineering and
            construction management services and training.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Sichuan Power Transmission Project
            : environmental impact assessment report

abstracts.cdata!:
The purposes of the environmental
            assessment report are to: 1) forecast the short- and
            long-term adverse environmental impacts of the project; 2)
            adopt a series of protection measures so as to eliminate
            or/and minimize the adverse environmental impacts during the
            construction and operation periods; 3) establish the
            environmental facilities and carry out environmental
            monitoring as well as supervise the implementation of
            protection measures; and 4) calculate the investment needed
            for environmental protection.  The study analyzes the
            impacts of the project on: forests, mineral resources,
            wildlife and conservation areas, scenery and aesthetics and
            farmland.  The study also discusses the impacts of the
            environment on the transmission line such as: unfavorable
            geological conditions, high elevations, heavy icing, air
            pollution, and forest fires.
